discussion.content: Hello. Why is not --> D. Fiber optic ?

comments.content:
"The technician will be running the cables in the air return space above the drop ceiling"
Whenever you see anything about cables being ran in the ceiling, it's going to be plenum cabling, which is ethernet with a special coating. NOT fiber otic.

questions.question_text: A network technician needs to install new network cables. The technician will be running the cables in the air return space above the drop ceiling. Which of the following cable types should be installed?

A new employee is unable to access any network resources. All other users are able to access the network at 100Mbps. No IP address, subnet mask, or default gateway is displayed on the new employee's workstation. The network administrator reterminates all connectors using the correct standard. Upon further investigation, the network administrator also notices the following:
Wire map results from the user patch cable to the patch cable connecting to the switch:
✑ Pins 5 and 7 are short.
✑ The distance is 200ft (61m).
Additional observations on the switch:
✑ The VLAN is set correctly.
✑ The port is not disabled.
✑ The duplex/speed settings are correct.
✑ Port LEDs are off for that port.
✑ The port is set to untagged.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason the new employee is having network issues?

discussion.content:
On 100Mbps networks with a cat5 cable you only need 2 pairs of cables to work. Pins 1,2,3,6.
 So Pins 5 and 7 can be short and still have a working cable for this particular situation. I had to Google this because I've seen this type of question more than once where shorts weren't the answer. https://www.electronics-notes.com/articles/connectivity/ethernet-ieee-802-3/cables-types-pinout-cat-5-5e-6.php

comments.content: The administrator reterminated all the connectors using the correct standard, so the only choice it could possibly be is a bad switchport
I would also like to know this, if anyone can explain?
"The network administrator reterminates all connectors using the correct standard."

discussion.content: Why wouldn’t in be open/short pin 5 and 7 are short
Password policies apply to your credentials nearly just as much as your passwords.

questions.question_text: Which of the following would MOST likely contain information about credential reuse?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
An ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) request operates at the Data Link layer of the OSI model. ARP is used to map an IP address (which operates at the Network layer) to a MAC address (which operates at the Data Link layer). The ARP request "Who is 192.168.1.200? Tell 192.168.1.55" is used to find the MAC address corresponding to the IP address 192.168.1.200.

Therefore, the correct answer is:
B. Data link

ARP works between Layers 2 and 3. The MAC address exists on Layer 2, the data link layer. The IP address exists on Layer 3, the network layer. Based on the context of this question, the given answer is correct.
Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) is a layer 2 protocol used to map MAC addresses to IP addresses.
Should be a "D": Network. ARP operates at layer 3
ARP happens at layer 2, where switches operate

questions.question_text:
An ARP request is broadcasted and sends the following request:
"Who is 192.168.1.200? Tell 192.168.1.55"
At which of the following layers of the OSI model does this request operate?

discussion.content: Just as is the case with so many of these questions, re-reading them again and again can change your approach on them. If "technician tests the components with a PoE injector at the switch" implies the technician brought the phone with him to the switch for the test then, yes, damaged cable would be correct. Another unclear aspect of the question is that we don't know how the phone was originally getting power...from the injector or the switch port? Was the PoE injector introduced only as part of the test? If the phone was not brought to the switch for the test and the phone was originally getting power from the switch port then bad switch port would be appropriate.

The introduction of a PoE injector at the switch is doing only one thing and changing only 1 thing...sending power through the EXISTING CABLING. If the phone powers up after adding the injector at the switch using the EXISTING CABLING, then the switchport is bad (as in the switchport is unable to provide the power). Going with bad switchport on this one.

comments.content:
Since a PoE injector is being used every other option are eliminated except damaged cables
https://intellinetnetwork.eu/pages/what-is-a-poe-injector

questions.question_text: A VoIP device is not getting power at a new user's desk. The technician tests the components with a PoE injector at the switch and resolves the issue. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?
